description: Criminal Law in context involves the study of the general principles of criminal responsibility and procedure and examines how specific offences are made, defined, prosecuted and defended. The course examines how the operation of different institutions and actors (public and private police, prosecution, courts, defendants, juries, corrections) shape the boundaries of the criminal law, focusing on the role of discretion and public interest/policy considerations.
restricted: Restricted to students enrolled in the Bachelor of Criminology and Criminal Justice (Honours)
